summary: John Hickam (Chris Cooper) is a West Virginia coal miner who loves his job and expects his sons, Jim (Scott Miles) and Homer (Jake Gyllenhaal), to follow in his footsteps. But Jim gets a football scholarship, and Homer becomes interested in rocket science after seeing Sputnik 1 crossing the sky. John disapproves of his son's new mania, but Homer begins building rockets with the help of friends and a sympathetic teacher (Laura Dern). Rocketry, he hopes, will prove his ticket to a better life.

reviews.content: Following a dream and making it come true has been seen enough times to count them with an abacus. What this cliché has in its favor here is a correctly written script that does not appeal to opportunistic and simple sentimentality, and an interesting cast.

October Sky is a heartwarming and inspiring movie that captures the essence of determination, passion, and perseverance. The film, directed by Joe Johnston, tells the true story of Homer Hickam, a young boy from a small coal-mining town in West Virginia who dreams of building rockets and launching them into space.

One of the reasons why October Sky is such a great movie is its ability to draw the audience into the story and make them feel invested in the characters. The film portrays the struggles and challenges faced by Homer and his friends as they pursue their dream of building rockets, while also dealing with the expectations and limitations imposed by their families and community.

The performances of the cast are another standout feature of October Sky. Jake Gyllenhaal, who plays the lead role of Homer, delivers a nuanced and emotional performance that captures the character's determination and passion. The supporting cast, including Chris Cooper as Homer's father and Laura Dern as his teacher, also deliver memorable performances that bring depth and complexity to the story.

The movie also touches on several themes that resonate with audiences, such as the importance of following one's dreams and the power of education to change lives. These themes are woven into the fabric of the story and provide a sense of depth and meaning that elevates the film beyond a simple coming-of-age tale.

Overall, October Sky is a heartwarming and inspiring movie that captures the essence of the American Dream. It is a powerful reminder of the importance of pursuing one's dreams and the impact that determination, passion, and perseverance can have in our lives. It is a movie that will leave you feeling uplifted, inspired, and grateful for the human spirit.

Joe Johnston's historical coming of age drama October Sky (1999) is a picture burning with passion for science, discovery, education, family, and fellowship among men. Joe Johnston's direction is as peerless and enjoyable as any iconic director's grounded style. October Sky is as much a coming of age drama story like Stand by Me or Lady Bird as it is a film about coal miners, unions, and small town mindsets like Matewan or Coal Miner's Daughter. 

I always find director Joe Johnston's films to be kind hearted and focused on inspiring kids to remember themselves, to seek higher education in life, understand their parents, and for parents to empathize with their children. Lewis Colick's writing understands how teenagers talk among each other, wanting their desires to be in life, while sympathizing with the perspective and struggles of both children and their parents. October Sky may just help you pick your path in life.

I believe October Sky creates a passion for rocket science and mathematics, while also making you want to go out and make friends, find a hobby, pursue a career you love, find love, and rekindle the love in your family. October Sky is made with love and care like all great Joe Johnston films like The Rocketeer, Jumanji, Honey I Shrunk the Kids, Captain America The First Avenger, or Hidalgo. October Sky is worth seeing for the rocket launches alone, let alone the life affirming true story about a boy wanting to leave his town to build rockets and gain his father's respect.

Jake Gyllenhaal is so sensitive and compelling as Homer Hickam, who figures his chance out of town is in building rockets. His frustrations and fears are apparent on Gyllenhaal's face. He was a fine actor before Donnie Darko, Brokeback Mountain, or Nightcrawler even. Laura Dern is so sweet and supportive as Homer's kind teacher Miss Riley. I don't know of a nicer performance in film from a lovelier actress than Laura Dern. 

Chris Cooper is one mean, jaded, and reactionary father figure as Homer's tough father and mining boss John Hickam. It's cool to see Cooper do a mining picture after John Sayles' iconic Matewan with Cooper as the union creating leader, now an older man desperate to keep the livelihoods of his town in operation in a failing coal industry. Natalie Canerday is great as Homer's mother Elsie Hickam. Chris Owen is wonderful as the brainiac nerd Quentin Wilson alongside the other boys William Lee Scott and Chad Lindberg portray. I liked the nice girl Valentine Carmina as portrayed by Kaili Hollister. 

Robert Dalva's editing cuts quickly in montages of rocket building, launching, and exploding for a delightful series of training montages in rocket science. His sharp cuts make October Sky's 108 fly by like a rocket in the sky. Fred Murphy's cinematography uses natural scenery of forests in lush wide shots to deep and dark close-ups in the depths of the mines for a harsher effect. Jim Mitchell and Mark S. Miller's visual effects for the rocket launches are second to none and highly realistic. Mark Isham's score is lovely and definitely gets me emotional hearing his tender melodies. Betsy Cox' costumes look like the early 1950's and 1960's for sure.

In conclusion, October Sky delights me now as it did for me as a child. Any family should find a light of compassion and inspiration in watching it today.

"October Sky" is a pretty good movie with pretty good performances. Maybe even great, but I don't believe that it's one of the greatest family masterpieces it's often made out to be. The story was relatively interesting, starring a young Jake Gyllenhaal as real-life NASA engineer Homer Hickam. After the Soviet satellite Sputnik was sent into space, it instantly caught Hickam's interests and he knew that this was what he was going to do. His family doesn't believe in him, his town doesn't believe in him but one teacher does and it changes his life. I'm sorry, I know this is a true story and all but this movie is very predictable, around the half-way mark you know exactly what's going to happen almost in the order that it ends up doing. That makes the movie feel much longer than it is, probably didn't help that I was also watching it with my family very late at night. They frequently asked me "how much longer?" It's by no means a bad movie, not at all. It's average-length but just seems drawn out as the entire story could've easily been told in the span of 10 minutes. Ah, well. Still pretty good family movie, one of the better ones I think I've actually seen and I'd recommend it actually. I liked it, even though a lot of my sleepy siblings didn't. It's quite an inspiring tale of believing in yourself when no one else would but it just falls a little short for my personal tastes. It's still an excellent family movie though.
It's pretty formulaic. Most of the usual cliches are here. The story is kind of interesting but nothing extraordinary.

This movie is one of my absolute favorites of all time. I don't think any other movie does such a good job of telling an inspirational story about a kid from a small town with a really big dream. This is the ultimate "feel good" movie, but it also does a great job of capturing the relationship between Homer and everyone around him, particularly the relationship between him and his dad. The movie does such a mature job of capturing the conflict between their perspectives, as well as developing Homer's character and making us all root for him to land his big shot of winning the national science fair and being able to pursue greater goals. While I may be biased towards this movie, as I often feel like Homer myself, it is still undoubtedly a great film.
To those who say this is a merely a conventional "feel good" movie, I say the acting sets this apart from those typical films.  Jake Gyllenhaal and Chris Cooper are amazing.

Can we all agree that any movie set in the 1950s should be directed by Joe Johnston? He has a magical way of capturing the nostalgic feel of that era. The way we are introduced to Coalwood, West Virginia makes you feel like this place has been around for generations. It’s a quaint small town where everyone knows everyone else, and there’s closeness throughout the entire community. The cast nailed the accents across the board (even if sometimes they look like they are doing a little extra work with their mouths to make it sound right.) The costume and set designers made everything look perfect. It all comes together to give October Sky an amazing sense of place and time that is authentic. You never get the sense that just off camera there is a studio or something, because the film takes you to Coalwood. I love the story of this rag-tag group of kids who work together to do something that seems improbable so that they can move on to bigger and better things. The scenes of them experimenting and figuring out all the little details they need to make a successful rocket were great. It helps that the cast of actors was excellent. However, I often have trouble with movies that include a character like the one Chris Cooper plays. He appears so unfeeling and insensitive throughout the film, that I find myself getting mad. It’s even more tragic because it is a father-son relationship, and I want him to show his love by supporting his son instead of cutting him down. I’m aware that the conflict is necessary to add drama to the story, and I imagine some of it was based in real events, but it’s hard for me to watch. That being said, the lows that the film reaches makes the highs seem more thrilling and exciting. Speaking of lows and highs, that’s one of the things I love about October Sky, the blatant symbolism of Homer Hickam’s life is astounding. If it wasn’t based on a true story, you’d want to chastise the author for making the story too good to be true. The idea that Homer doesn’t want to go down and be buried in the mine, but longs to soar into the heavens is delightful. Joe Johnston used that idea to full effect in this film, and there are a few shots that show the contrast of the two worlds so well I’ll never forget them. While there were certain elements of October Sky that didn’t click for me, I still enjoyed the story a lot, and it is one film I expect to revisit and fall in love with more in the future.

I can't believe it took me this long to see this movie, especially since I like Jake Gyllenhaal and Chris Cooper. Cooper is a miner in a mining town in West Virginia and Gyllenhaal, who plays his son doesn't want to go into the family business. He wants to be a rocket scientist. It's based on a true story. It's no academy award winning movie, but it's very charming and so is Jake Gyllinhall. He's very young in it. The acting by everyone in it is adequate. Everything about it technically is adequate.  There's a fun little montage of them shooting, or trying to shoot of their rockets and failing over and over. The sound track was all 60's music which was enjoyable. Although a little predictable and a little derivative it was still pretty entertaining and enjoyable. Maybe because it's just so disgustingly feel good. I cried despite myself at the end. It's also just one of the most family oriented movies ever. If you have the whole family over and don't want to offend anyone, this is the perfect movie for that occasion. There's footage of the real people at the end of the movie. It's pretty fascinating.

One of my favorite films since I saw it when I was nine years old. October Sky is a film that captures the excitement and the imagination of four teenage boys who believed they could do anything. Director Joe Johnston perfectly recreates mid-century West Virginia in a way that only he could do, and allows his cast to do most of the leg work. Jake Gyllenhaal leads the amazing cast, which features Laura Dern, Chris Cooper, and Natalie Canerday, all of whom give powerful performances. A film that could have simply been about a journey to the stars actually becomes about a strained father-son relationship. If the conclusion of the film doesn't have you in tears, you don't have a soul.

Gyllenhaal and the other young actors all manage to create unique characters (thanks in part to good writing).  The movie manages to tap into memories of looking to the skies and marveling at the stars with a skill that rarely is seen. Homer H. Hickam Jr plays a young man growing up in a small town of Coalwood in WV. in the 1950's. After a night of residents coming together to watch the first man made satellite launched, Homer glances at the shooting star with amazement, it ultimately inspires him to start building rockets and learning more about science, and his least successful subject math, with the help of his friends, anything becomes possible, and the town is delighted by their high flying rockets. This is a heartwarming film with a great acting performance by Jake Gyllenhaal. There comes a time when a movie based on a true story is a winner, and this is one of them. The best and the most unforgetful scene would be when the father shows up with the town's people to show support for his son, though he wanted him to walk in his footsteps as a coal miner.

This is more than a great movie, it's a classic. Jake Gyllehaal is one of those actors that you can't quit watching, and you don't want to. A true story that warms the heart and inspires you to search for more, what your passionate about. A young boy growing up in Coalwood WV living with his firm father, sweet mother and athletic jock brother, Homer is expected to become a coal miner, but when he witness the first man made satellite in the nightly sky, he becomes interested in science and space, he decides to start building rockets with his friends, starting out as failure and turning it into a success when he enters a Science fair and gets to travel outside of his home town, the only place he's known. The ending is a perfect fix to what was missing throughout the movie, a son and his father sharing that bond that was truly heartwarming.

The Tragedy of Being Smarter Than Your Parents  

It can be hard to explain sometimes.  I am told that my father was incredibly intelligent, though I was too young at the time he died to have known.  My mother is not a stupid woman by any stretch of the imagination, but let us say that this is one of the many areas where I take after my father.  Mom was never anything but supportive, which may well have been in part because she had known my dad.  However, I never really felt that she understood.  How much worse would it have been if my mother had never had reason to understand or respect intelligence?  If she had seen my interest as betraying everything she stood for?  I don't know how many generations of this family worked in the mines, but it is true that the very idea of going to college meant Our Hero's turning his back on what his family stood for, what his father had done with his life.  It was intimidating to his father, and that's the great sorrow of the movie.

Our Hero is Homer Hickham (Jake Gyllenhaal).  In October of 1957, he and his friends watched [i]Sputnik 1[/i] make its way across the sky, and they heard its beeping on the radio.  And Homer thought, "That's my future."  He enlisted local nerd Quentin Wilson (Chris Owen) and Homer's friends Roy Lee Cooke (William Lee Scott) and Sherman O'Dell (Chad Lindberg), and together, they start building rockets.  The first ones aren't very good, but they get better and better.  However, Homer's father, John (Chris Cooper), isn't interested.  Homer's brother, Jim (Scott Miles), is a local football hero, and John respects that, but he doesn't respect the physics and trigonometry Homer is learning.  It only gets worse when the boys are accused of starting a forest fire with one of their rockets.  Homer has the support of the entire town, including teacher Freida J. Riley (Laura Dern), but not his father, despite the efforts of his mother, Elsie (Natalie Canerday).

It's sad, really.  The town was dying; there is no Coalwood, West Virginia anymore.  Traditionally, football was what let boys escape, when they could escape--football players got college scholarships.  Part of the conflict is that Homer is shown to know that, while his father did not.  His father is a coal miner, and that's all he knows.  He wants his boys to come and work in the coal mine, too; by turning his back on the mine, Homer is turning his back on his father.  (Though I can't help wondering what happened to girls who wanted to escape; they must have had even fewer options.)  The real-life Homer Hickham (who is a junior; his father's name is changed in this to avoid confusion) got out, but how many of his classmates went down into the mines when the mines closed?  How many died either in the mines or from mining-related causes?  It's still one of the most dangerous jobs in the US.  This country runs on coal still, and we need coal miners.  But coal mining is a hard life, and most of the boys in this movie never had any other choice.

The movie is sentimental almost to the point of syrup in places, but you know, it's good to see American ingenuity the focus of a family film.  For once, it isn't about the jocks, though the disc does come with a trailer for the movie of [i]Friday Night Lights[/i].  For once, it's the science fair that's what the town is cheering for.  And in many ways, that's how it should be; it's a lot easier to get out of a small town from being smart than being athletic.  There aren't enough spots on college football teams to take all the stars of the high school football teams, and there aren't enough spots in the pros to take all the stars of the college football teams.  If you can get an academic scholarship--and need-based grants--you've got a shot at a career that athletics can't necessarily provide.  We seem to spend too much screen time idolizing the careers that are hardest to get into, and while not everyone can be a rocket scientist, we do as a nation need to be training more engineers.

I don't think everyone will understand the aspect of the movie which spoke most to me.  After all, the movie still does include Quentin to be mocked.  Even when the boys are the talk of the town, Homer assures Quentin that the girls still think he's weird.  Homer is expressly acknowledged to have difficulty with math.  However, if he's even of slightly above average intelligence, Homer is still smarter than most of the people around him, and his drive further sets him apart.  Heck, without him, Roy Lee and O'Dell would have gone down into the mines just like everyone else in town.  Leon Bolden (Randy Stripling) had been a Tuskegee Airman; while he works as an engineer, he still works for the mine.  Half the reason Homer goes down into the mine when he does is that the company owns their house and most of their furniture.  It doesn't seem to occur to his father that the kind of job Homer could get with an education would more than pay for their own house and furniture.

"October Sky", from a plot standpoint, may not be the most original film of its decade.  It comes from the same warm, character-driven formula that made films like "Hoosiers" and "Rudy" so successful, but it is oddly this same charming quality that makes "October Sky" such a gem.  What "Hoosiers" and "Rudy" did for sports, "October Sky" does for science and education; it celebrates a human accomplishment against all odds.  It is this rare quality, in addition to a witty screenplay, an array of fine performances, sharp direction by Joe Johnston, and a heartbreaking score by Mark Isham that make "October Sky" one of the finest "Hollywood" dramas of the 90s.  That this film is actually based on a true story by NASA engineer Homer Hickam makes it even more valuable--you wouldn't trade it for a pot of gold.

The story consists of Homer Hickam Jr., who lives in  the mining town of Coalwood where you either go to college on a football scholarship, or work in the coal mine. Homer baffles everyone by trying to build rockets. He enlists the help of his friends and an unpopular nerd genius to try and show the town that they can win the science fair against all odds. It's got lovable characters and a great storyline. I love it.

I love historic films.  Especially films that are so compelling that the narrative can focus on the story aspect instead of working hard to sell the audience that they're in another time.  October Sky is a simple, but heartfelt tale about Homer H. Hickman, a man who I never knew existed prior to this film's release.  Homer grew up in a small town, but dreams to live a life better than what his stomping grounds can offer.  A tale many of us can relate to.  But this is also a story about winning the love of your father, and never giving up on your dreams no matter how impossible they seem.  Speaking to us with these universal themes, director Joe Johnston delivers a powerful drama that will move you to tears.  Highly recommended.  This film is just a delight.

'October Sky' is a good retelling of actual events of how a team of boys who want to escape life underground in Coalwood, West Virginia, where coal mining is king. But by October 4, 1957, when the Soviet satellite Sputnik flies overhead in the night sky, Homer Hickam Jr.'s life is changed forever. So with the help of his teacher, he and his three buddies start an amateur rocket program way out of the town limits. Even with his father's disapproval, a limited education, and a series of misfires that threaten his dreams and the town, Homer overcomes seemingly impossible odds to achieve his vision of earning his college scholarship and working in rocket science later in his lifetime. And he brought us this inspiring drama of his life, all immortalized on the screen.

Based on the real Homer Hickam Jr.'s book 'Rocket Boys' and directed by Joe Johnston, 'October Sky' has good acting performances. I liked Jake Gyllenhaal's young Hickam character as well as his sense of individuality. Supporting Gyllenhaal includes Laura Dern (Ms. Riley) and Chris Cooper (John Hickam), both of which were very interesting characters. The film soundtrack is so inspiring for the 1950s setting; Buddy Holly's "That'll Be The Day" and sometimes the background instrumentals really sets me in a good mood.

What can I say about 'October Sky'? It's a great historical drama for all audiences to enjoy, including the 1950s-era fans and the rocket scientists of the world.

This is the true story of Homer Hickam, Jr.- a bright teenager obsessed with rockets and science who, much to the befuddlement of his family and neighbors of his small, working class coal mining town, defied the odds to follow his dreams during the space race years of the 50s. 

It's a very inspiring story that is filled with heart, warmth, humor, and does a good job at dealing with issues of family, working class life, and following one's dreams. That, and it's got a notable cast including a young Jake Gyllenhaal, Chris Cooper, and Laura Dern.

Hickam did eventually become a NASA engineer, but the film primarily focuses on the earliest leg of that journey, and the scenes of him and his friends trying to get into the rocket game for themselves are both funny and charming. 

This is Joe Johnston making a nice drama and pulling it off pretty well. He's got a spotty record, but this is one of his better efforts, and one I find my self enjoying quite a bit each time I see it. Sure, there are shades of typical tropes like the father wanting the son to follow in his footsteps, and people interested in a subject that doesn't fit in with what everyone else in their locale appreciates, but it's handled decently, and the performances are nice, too.
The writing is not always spectacular, but October sky is a fully inspirational story that is never afraid to show its emotions.

"One dream is enough to light up the entire sky."

       A touching and emotionally charged triumph from Director Joe Johnston (Honey, I Shrunk The Kids, Jumanji).  October Sky is based on the truly inspirational childhood story of NASA Engineer Homer Hickham Jr. and his journey through a tough adolescence.  Overcoming tough family, social and educational issues, Homer was able to conquer the impossible, and in doing so, inspired an entire town.  Homer, along with his childhood friends (nicknamed "The Rocket Boys") are all examples of pure determination and integrity.  It's just a towering film that does everything right, it's not overly dramatic, it's littered with humor and it captivates you with it's very intense emotional concepts.  I'm a sucker for true stories, when they're done right, they can be a vessel to endlessly amazing stories and people.  October Sky is a stirring and engaging piece of expert craftmanship from acclaimed director Joe Johnston, it's tremendously powerful, spectacularly inspirational, amazingly intriguing, emotionally gripping and undeniably superb.  A film that should be shown to every student in every school, a perfect example of the timeless saying...you can do anything you put your mind to.  This one will sear itself into your memory and stay with you forever.  A small town American story that will forever have a place in your heart.  It's a slow-moving, but tensely told story that you won't be able to take your attention from.  A beautiful American story that's unlike anything you'll ever see. 
          The acting is excellent with brilliant performances from everyone involved.  Jake Gyllenhaal is excellent, Chris Cooper is brilliant, Laura Dern is great and Chris Owen does well too.  The talent shines in every scene.  The story was spectacular to begin with, but factor in the brilliant talents of the cast, it truly does click on all cylinders.
One of the best dramas of all time. It makes you feel smarter by the end. I once wanted to be an astronaut. The story line is fantastic.

An absolutely oustanding film. October sky is an incredibly touching film that tells a wonderfull story about teens in a small forgotten town who want to do something more than just the expected. The movie really does an excellent job at recreating an old forgotten town and brings back the look and feel of the late 50s. This is essential as this helps set the tone and mood. But the anchor of the film is Jake Gyllenhaal. He gives a rich performance as the well meaning and somewhat spontaneous teenager who dreams of something more than what is expected of him. He is a very sympathetic character because he feels emotions and goes through things that many people can relate to. The other great performance is Chris Cooper as his strict and rahter unsupportive father. The drama between father and son is honest and touching and creates some very good tension. But above all October Sky is about chasing dreams and the determination to succeed despite what others may say or think and succeeds at being an authentic and honest tale of inspiration. Very highly recomended
A wonderful, uplifting, realistic film

Hmm. . .well that was refreshing. I can honestly say that after watching Joe Johnston's "October Sky" I feel a whole lot better about everything. Truly just an overwhelmingly inspiring and uplifting film. I mean you could take the most cynical, mysanthropic soul on this planet, have him watch "October Sky", and he'd have a healthier outlook on his life. I swear, during the last 10 minutes of this movie, I had the biggest shit-eating grin on my face - one of those endings you just can't help but get caught up in. The film features an abundant amount of fine performances. Namely, Jake Gyllenhaal's portrayal of Homer Hickam, and Chris Cooper's compelling turn as his father, John. Other great performances came from Laura Dern, Chris Owen, William Lee Scott, and Chad Lindberg. The movie is shot to a magnificent degree. For instance, Cinematographer Fred Murphy really uses dismal lighting to magnify the miserable atmosphere within Coalwood, West Virginia. The movie is also edited to a tee. "October Sky" also possesses a brilliantly written screenplay that effectively tells the story with emotion as well as convey the narratives heartwarming themes. Overall, I feel that "October Sky" is an awe-inspiring coming-of-age tale of perseverance, respect, and hope. It's a movie that everyone can learn something from. I know I did.

October Sky is a film heavy on the stereotypes and the clichÃ (C)s of hard life in the south. It focuses on the life of a real person, Homer Hickham(played by Jake Gyllenhaal), and his struggle to fulfill his passion in a town where getting a scholarship is a million to one shot and mining coal is the only way of life. I had originally seen this movie when I was about 10, and it was always one of my favorites. I loved the violin music that complements the nice cinematography showcasing the grit of West Virginia in 1957. The acting was also very good, even though it may have been stereotyped a big, and the language slacked a little. Chris Cooper plays a convincing and frustrated father who works opposite Jake Gyllenhaal who is a bright young man with huge dreams. The story is something we've all seen before but just can't stop watching. Joe Johnston, the director, created a very well made movie that makes us feel good as others like "Remember the Titans, " or "The Shawshank Redemption," did. But again, who can ever tire of that formula? So, looking back at it now, there are some spotty parts and the chances of the 4 "Rocket-boys," actually winning the Science Fair is scarce, but what makes it all tie together is the fact that it was based on a true story. We can sympathize with the 4 boys because their life is so tough and realistic it's almost heart-breaking to imagine what would've happened if they hadn't won the Science Fair. The way the movie plays out is almost like a Stephen King type story, where there are 4 boys all in a hick town where nothing good ever happens. Well, this is what a Stephen King story would most likely look like if it had a happy ending. Which is common in a movie like this, and yeah, how often does your dad who hates you ever come to see you perform on your last show? In this movie it appears probable. For those who may not understand the film's intent, just get it cleared out of the way before you watch the movie, that it IS meant to be uplifting and some what inspirational. I know it was for me when I was 10, and I still look back on it fondly as a favorite.

There are not enough superlatives in the English language to adequately celebrate the qualities of this movie. Director Joe Johnston handles this poetic examination of a teenage boy's unquenchable desire to cut his own path in life with a tenderness and affection for his subject. Gyllenhaal is extraordinary as the younger son of a West Virginia coal miner, determined to escape the gravitational pull of the coal mine while desperately trying to earn his father's understanding and respect. Chris Cooper shows he's one of the best actors working today with his gritty, totally genuine portrayal of John Hickam, the father struggling to come to terms with his son's maverick aspirations of a life far from the coal seams of Appalachia. The supporting cast is universally outstanding, particularly Laura Dern as Homer's inspirational high school teacher. Mark Isham's score, rich in bluegrass-y fiddle solos, beautifully captures the spiritual essence of the film. One of my top ten favorite films of all time.

October Sky ins the best feel good movie ever made. One of the things thats great about the film is the film doesn't go over board in it's sentimentality. Never does it feel overly sentimental, corny or embarrassing. This is the type of film that you will definitely feel good right after watching it.  You really sympathize with the characters because they are brilliantly played by the cast. I can't recall the number of times I've seen this film, but it's at least over a dozen times. Unlike other family films that try to be overly sentimental just for the sake of being family friendly and to appeal to a bigger audience. October Sky has something that separates it from other feel good films, and thats a very good story, and I mean good. October Sky is the true story of Homer Hickam a teenager who spots the Sputnik satellite and who decides to built his own rocket and enter the science fair. His dad is highly against it, and wants him to work in the mine. Homer has other ideas. October Sky is really a story about accomplishing your dreams, and achieving the impossible. This is simply an incredible story about perseverance and determination and unlike other feel good films, this is a true story, and the way it's told on film is beautiful. The film is brilliantly directed by Joe Johnson, director of Jumanji, and he crafts yet another great film. October Sky is a well acted film, the actors here are incredible and this was one of Jake Gyllenhaal's first staring roles, and is just the right person for this role.  Also a performance that is equally great is Chjris Cooper as Homer's father who opposes Homer's dreams. Both actors electrifying as they butt heads on screen as we see their conflicting ideas unfold. Chris Cooper is fine and underrated actor, and this is the first film that I've seen that exposed me to his work. October Sky is a solid feel good film and like I said, this is one of the best too. A fine cast upholds this film, and Johnson has got a fine script at hand. and because of that, the film works very well. The beauty part about this film is that this is the type of film that will stay with you long after you've seen it, and everyone can take something positive away from it. A fine film that in one word can be summarized as beautiful.

This movie is set in the 1960's and based on the true story told in the novel "Rocket Boys."  The story follows the life of four boys from a small coal-mining town.  The main character, Homer Hickman, wants to be a rocket scientist, not a coal miner.  The movie is a great inspiration to anyone who has a dream to do more with their life than people expect of them.  The acting in this movie is excellent.  Jake Gyllenhaal and Laura Dern were particularly powerful in their roles.

Ever since this movie came out in 1999 my mother has been telling me to watch it. Being the movie lover I am, it's hard to believe I hadn't taken the time until today. Over the years, I've heard nothing but praise for October Sky - the characters, the story, "it's just so good!" - and my mother was right. 
 
Based on a true story, October Sky is one of the most heartwarming, uplifting films I've seen in a long time. It features incredible performances from Jake Gyllenhaal, Chris Cooper, Laura Dern and a host of other actors, whose characters add to the story's depth and charm. I laughed, I cried, I loved every moment, and I highly recommend seeing it. Don't wait 11 years like I did.

Okay, I'll try to keep this review short and brief.  First off, I was sick with the chicken pox when I first watched this film.  So, I can't remember everything exactly, but what I really know is this:  I really liked the film.  I don't know a lot about the true story, but let's stick to the basics of the film.  
     There was great acting, directing, and it was well written for the screen.  Everything seemed to flow smoothly from start to finish and the boys' in the film make you feel somewhat inspired.  I would also like to mention that there is a great score composed by Mark Isham accompanying the film.  
     For the content, there is some language including a few profanities and vulgarities along with a briefly scene obscene hand gesture.  There are also a few mild swear words scattered throughout the film.  However, swearing is used infrequently.  Other than that, a few rockets blow up and almost injure some people, and we also see some injured coal miners and see the danger they face every day.
     All that being said, "October Sky" is a great movie that I highly recommend!  4 1/2 stars.

Set in the late 1950s, October Sky is about a group of young boys in a coal-mining town. Homer, the main character is obsessed with launching rockets and with the inspiration of a schoolteacher comes from building rockets in the basement against his fathers will to designing components and showing them off in a national science fare. The film is a classic about a group of friends achieving something that wouldnt be impossible without each other.  In the film Homer (Jake Gyllenhaal) struggles to avoid the dead end life of a coal minor, that his father wants him to come and take over the coal mining business, which is not what he wants to become. 

The Director Joe Johnston wittedly conjures up the 1950s teenage social order.  Johnston also places the town  out  of the way of anything that survives off mining where everybody belives that mining is the only way to survive and feed their families. During one school year, Homer and the rocket boys blast off into futures their parents didn't decide for them. Corny? Sure, but it is a movie that almost everybody will love.

Towards the end of the movie you see everybody that was once in his way step aside and help him to become a part of NASA, but that's another story. Personally I thought it was a great movie but I found the story very traditional, meaning that I found that it was about the same thing with nothing overly appealing. To me it was about love, friends, and reaching what appears to be the impossible that turns out to be not so impossible. Overall I loved it and would watch it again, as it was not painful to watch.

Having all this in mind, the film is a fine line between a classic story of friends and reaching your dreams. I found the movie a great movie for anyone looking for a movie that combines friends, love and fun.

When I first saw this movie in 8th grade Language Arts class, I thought "Hmm, another boring movie". But then as it got deeper into the film I thought "Holy crap, this is a damn good movie!" And then class ended. The performances were outstanding, and the story is truly inspiring to people to let them chase their dreams and let nothing stop them.

Of all the movies I've had to watch in a schoolroom in my life, October Sky is my favorite. Jake Gyllenhaal plays a wonderful role as Homer, an oppressed student who longs to break free of the gloomy mining town he lives in. He sees his chance when he witnesses the launch of Sputnik, and organizes a team of his classmates and friends that builds their own rockets. Homer learns through aeronautics about friendship, his future, and most importantly, pursuing your dreams no matter what the cost.
A good ture story about simple times and focused efforts.
A classic under dog story where the final success is as gratifying as it is inevitable.

There are many moments in October Sky that will induce that revealing lump in your throat.  It's an inspiring, feel-good story about a son pursuing his dreams all the while trying desperately to earn the respect of a doubting father.  The only unfortunate aspect of the film is two unfathomable characters, one whose presence is critical to the plot.

Was Homer Hickman Sr. really that opposed to his son pursuing rocketry?  In the world I come from, that is unimaginable.  Realizing this all takes place in the infancy of space exploration, it is reasonable to suspect a coal mining superintendent would encourage his son to follow him into the mines.  But the level of obsession written in for this character reeks of exaggeration.  It heightens the conflict, but I couldn't help but roll my eyes through some of those scenes shared by father and son.

Even more perplexing was the school principal.  I found him to be a completely unrealistic character.

But enough with the negativity.  Anyone and everyone will enjoy this film.  The four youths, the "Rocket Boys", all bring something unique to the screen.  I always enjoy Natalie Canerday (Mrs. Hickam), mainly because I love that wonderful Sling Blade accent of hers. There is also an ample dose of humor to go along with the math and the various conflicts that arise.  And once the town gets behind these boys, it becomes quite a rollicking fun ride indeed.
In the movie Homer say's "You know, it, uh, won't fly unless somebody pushes the button." And the movie has truly flew past the whole sky. Truly Awesome!!!
Not a lot to say, it was a good movie with great performances.

a powerful and inspiring true story that takes our hearts on a fantastic ride. this film really makes you feel like you if you really set your mind and really want something, you can accomplish it. jake gyllenhal is fantastic as the lead role and gives a commanding performance. the story is epic, charming, and most of entertaining.

This film is truly moving and inspiring. It features a brilliant combination of angst, drama, and even a little comedy. Gyllenhaal and Cooper deserve many kudos, but also Natalie Canerday as the mother and William Lee Scott as Roy Lee deserve recognition. October Sky is representative of the era, not only from the "Sputnik" angle, but also the coal mining-company town aspect. 

The final scenes of the space shuttle's launch might never have come to fruition without the dedication of the Homer Hickams of this country. The post-Sputnik science-ed. sensation is certainly worthy of this fine treatment. I shared the pride that all of Coalwood felt when the "rocket boys" won the national science fair. The theme that hard work and dedication lead to success may seem old-fashioned, but here its done to perfection. It is not sugary nor schmaltzy, though it could have easily slipped into that trap. 

One more thought: my wife mocked the Appalachian accents a little, but I thought they were good, not overdone as southern accents usually are in movies.
